sp.p: But what now am I to say to my father? Am I to deny that I am ready, who have just promised to marry? With what effrontery could I presume to do that? I know not what to do with myself.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: apart. Nor I with myself, and yet I'm giving all due attention to it. I'll tell him that I will devise something, in order that I may procure some respite in this dilemma.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: catching sight of him. Oho!

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: apart. I'm seen.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: sneeringly. How now, good sir, what are you about? Do you see how dreadfully I am hampered by your devices?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Still, I'll soon extricate you.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: You, extricate me?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Assuredly, Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: As you have just done, I suppose.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Why no, better, I trust.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p:
What, am I to believe you, you scoundrel? You scoundrel: "Furcifer;" literally, wearer of the "furca," or wooden collar. This method of punishment has been referred to in the Notes to the Translation of Plautus. You, indeed, make good a matter that's all embarrassment and
ruin! Just see, in whom I've been placing reliance--you who this day from a most happy state have been and plunged me into a marriage. Didn't I say that this would be the case?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: You did say so.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: What do you deserve? What do you deserve?: Madame Dacier remarks that this question is taken from the custom of the Athenians, who never condemned a criminal without first asking him what punishment he thought he deserved; and according to the nature of his answer they mitigated or increased his punishment. The Commentators quote a similar passage from the Frogs of Aristophanes.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: The cross. The cross: The "cross," "crux," as a punishment for refractory slaves has been remarked upon in the Notes to the Translation of Plautus. But allow me a little time to recover myself; I'll soon hit upon something.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Ah me! not to have the leisure to inflict punishment upon you as I desire ! for the present conjuncture warns me to take precautions for myself, not to be taking vengeance on you. (Exeunt.)

div2.stage: Enter CHARINUS, wringing his hands.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p:
to himself. Is this to be believed or spoken of; that malice so great could be inborn in any one as to exult at misfortunes, and to derive advantage from the distresses of another! Oh, is this true? Assuredly, that is the most dangerous class of men, in whom there is only a slight degree of hesitation at refusing; afterward, when the time arrives for fulfilling their promises, then, obliged, of necessity they discover themselves. They are afraid, and yet the circumstances The circumstances: "Res." According, however, to Donatus, this word has the meaning here of "malice" or "spitefulness." compel them to refuse. Then, in that case, their very insolent remark is, "Who are you? What are you to me? What should I give up) to you what's my own? Look you, I am the most concerned in my own interests." Concerned in my own interests: Equivalent to our sayings, "Charity begins at home;" "Take care of number one." But if you inquire where is honor, they are not ashamed. They are not ashamed: Terence has probably borrowed this remark from the Epidicus of Plautus, 1. 165-6: "Generally all men are ashamed when it is of no use; when they ought to be ashamed, then does shame forsake them, when occasion is for them to be ashamed." Here, where there is occasion, they are not afraid; there, where there is no occasion, they are afraid. But what am I to do? Ought I not to go to him, and reason with him upon this outrage, and heap many an invective upon him? Yet some one may say, "you will avail nothing." Nothing? At least I shall have vexed him, and have given vent to my own feelings.
Enter PAMPHILUS and DAVUS.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Charinus, unintentionally I have ruined both myself and you, unless the Gods in some way befriend us.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Unintentionally, is it! An excuse has been discovered at last. You have broken your word.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: How so, pray?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Do you expect to deceive me a second time by these speeches?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: What does this mean?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Since I told you that I loved her, she has become quite pleasing to you. Ah wretched me! to have judged of your disposition from my own.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: You are mistaken.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Did this pleasure appear to you not to be quite complete, unless you tantalized me in my passion, and lured me on by groundless hopes?--You may take her.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I, take her? Alas! you know not in what perplexities, to my sorrow, I am involved, and what vast anxieties this executioner of mine pointing to DAVUS has contrived for me by his devices.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What is it so wonderful, if he takes example from yourself?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: You would not say that if you understood either myself or my affection.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm quite aware ironically; you have just now had a dispute with your father, and he is now angry with you in consequence, and has not been able to-day to prevail upon you to marry her.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: No, not at all,--as you are not acquainted with my sorrows, these nuptials were not in preparation for me; and no one was thinking at present of giving me a wife.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I am aware; you have been influenced by your own inclination.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Hold; you do not yet know all.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: For my part, I certainly do know that you are about to marry her.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Why are you torturing me to death? Listen to this. He pointing to DAVUS never ceased to urge me to tell my father that I would marry her; to advise and persuade me, even until he compelled me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Who was this person?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Davus.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Davus! For what reason?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I don't know; except that I must have been under the displeasure of the Gods, for me to have listened to him.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Is this the fact, Davus?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: It is the fact.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: starting. Ha! What do you say, you villain? Then may the Gods send you an end worthy of your deeds. Come now, tell me, if all his enemies had wished him to be plunged into a marriage, what advice but this could they have given?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I have been deceived, but I don't despair.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: ironically. I'm sure of that.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: This way it has not succeeded; we'll try another. Unless, perhaps, you think that because it failed at first, this misfortune can not now possibly be changed for better luck.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Certainly not; for I quite believe that if you set about it, you will be making two marriages for me out of one.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p:
I owe you this, Pamphilus, in respect of my servitude, to strive with hands and feet, night and day; to submit to hazard of my life, to serve you. It is your part, if any thing has fallen out contrary to expectation, to forgive
me. What I was contriving has not succeeded; still, I am using all endeavors; or, do you yourself devise something better, and dismiss me.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I wish to; restore me to the position in which you found me.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I'll do so.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: But it must be done directly.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: But the door of Glycerium's house here makes a noise. Makes a noise: The doors with the Romans opened in-wardly, while those of the Greeks opened on the outside. It was therefore usual with them, when coming out, to strike the door on the inside with a stick or with the knuckles, that those outside might be warned to get out of the way. Patrick, however, observes with some justice, that the word "concrepuit" may here allude to the creaking of the hinges. See the Curculio of Plautus, l. 160, where the Procuress pours water on the hinges, in order that Cappadox may not hear the opening of the door.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: That's nothing to you.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: assuming an attitude of meditation. I'm in search of----

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: ironically. Dear me, what, now at last?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Presently I'll give you what I've hit upon.

div2.stage: Enter MYSIS from the house of GLYCERIUM.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: calling at the door to GLYCERIUM within. Now, wherever he is, I'll take care that your own Pamphilus shall be found for you, and brought to you by me; do you only, my life, cease to vex yourself.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Mysis.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: turning round. Who is it? Why, Pamphilus, you do present yourself opportunely to me. My mistress charged me to beg of you, if you love her, to come to her directly; she says she wishes to see you.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: aside. Alas! I am undone; this dilemma grows apace! To DAVUS. For me and her, unfortunate persons, now to be tortured this way through your means; for I am sent for, because she has discovered that my marriage is in preparation.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: From which, indeed, how easily a respite could have been obtained, if he pointing to DAVUS had kept himself quiet.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: ironically to CHARINUS. Do proceed; if he isn't sufficiently angry of his own accord, do you irritate him.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: to PAMPHILUS., Aye faith, that is the case; and for that reason, poor thing, she is now in distress.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Mysis, I swear by all the Gods that I will never forsake her; not if I were to know that all men would be my enemies in consequence. Her have I chosen for mine; she has fallen to my lot; our feelings are congenial; farewell they, who wish for a separation between us; nothing but Death separates her from me.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: I begin to revive.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Not the responses of Apollo are more true than this. If it can possibly be contrived that my father may not believe that this marriage has been broken off through me, I could wish it. But if that can not be, I will do that which is easily effected, for him to believe that through me it has been caused. What do you think of me?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: That you are as unhappy as myself.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: placing his finger on his forehead. I'm contriving an expedient.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You are a clever hand; if you do set about any thing.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Assuredly, I'll manage this for you.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: There's need of it now.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: But I've got it now.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: For him (pointing to PAMPHILUS) I've got it, not for you, don't mistake.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm quite satisfied.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: What will you do? Tell me.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I'm afraid that this day won't be long enough for me to execute it, so don't suppose that I've now got leisure for relating it; do you betake yourself off at once, for you are a hinderance to me.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I'll go and see her. Goes into the house of GLYCERIUM.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: to CHARINUS. What are you going to do? Whither are you going from here?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Do you wish me to tell you the truth?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: No, not at all; aside he's making the beginning of a long story for me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Come now, you unreasonable person, are you not satisfied that I give you a little respite, by putting off his marriage?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But yet, Davus----

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: That I may marry her----

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Absurd.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Be sure to come hither pointing in the direction of his house to my house, if you can effect any thing.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Why should I come? I can do nothing for you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But still, if any thing----

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Well, well, I'll come.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: If you can; I shall be at home. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Do you, Mysis, remain here a little while, until I come out.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: There's a necessity for so doing.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Make haste.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I'll be here this moment, I tell you. He goes into the house of GLYCERIUM.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p:
to herself. That nothing can be secure to any one! Ye Gods, by our trust in you ! I used to make sure that this Pamphilus was a supreme blessing for my mistress; a friend, a protector, a husband secured under every circumstance; yet what anguish is she, poor thing, now suffering through him? Clearly there's more trouble for her now than there was happiness formerly. But Davus is coming out.
Enter DAVUS from the house of GLYCERIUM with the child.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: My good sir, prithee, what is that? Whither are you carrying the child?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Mysis, I now stand in need of your cunning being brought into play in this matter, and of your address.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Why, what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: holding out the child. Take it from me directly, and lay it down before our door.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Prithee, on the ground?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: pointing. Take some sacred herbs Take some sacred herbs: "Verbena" appears to have been a general term applied to any kind of herb used in honor of the Deities, or to the boughs and leaves of any tree gathered from a pure or sacred place. Fresh "verbenae" were placed upon the altars every day. See the Mercator of Plautus, 1. 672. from the altar here, From the altar here: It was usual to have altars on the stage; when Comedy was performed, one on the left hand in honor of Apollo, and on the representation of Tragedy, one on the right in honor of Bacchus. It has been suggested that Terence here alludes to the former of these. As, however, at Athens almost every house had its own altar in honor of Apollo Prostaterius just outside of the street door, it is most probable that to one of these altars reference is here made. They are frequently alluded to in the Plays of Plautus. and strew them under it.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Why don't you do it yourself?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: That if perchance I should have to swear to my master that I did not place it there, I may be enabled to do so with a clear conscience.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: I understand; have these new scruples only just now occurred to you, pray?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Bestir yourself quickly, that you may learn what I'm going to do next. MYSIS lays the child at SIMO'S door. Oh Jupiter!

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: starting up. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: The father of the intended bride is coming in the middle of it all. The plan which I had first purposed I now give up. Which I had first purposed, I now give up: His first intention no doubt was to go and inform Simo of the child being laid at the door.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: I don't understand what you are talking about.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I'll pretend too that I've come in this direction from the right. Do you take care to help out the conversation by your words, whenever there's necessity. Whenever there's necessity: He retires without fully explaining his intention to Mysis; consequently, in the next Scene she gives an answer to Chremes which Davus does not intend.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: I don't at all comprehend what you are about; but if there's any thing in which you have need of my assistance, as you understand the best, I'll stay, that I mayn't in any way impede your success. DAVUS retires out of sight.

div2.stage: Enter CHREMES on the other side of the stage, going toward the house of SIMO.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to himself After having provided the things necessary for my daughter's nuptials, I'm returning, that I may request her to be sent for. Seeing the child. But what's this? I'faith, it's a child. Addressing MYSIS. Woman, have you laid that here pointing to the child?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: aside, looking out for DAVUS. Where is he?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Don't you answer me?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: looking about, to herself. He isn't any where to be seen. Woe to wretched me! the fellow has left me and is off.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: coming forward and pretending not to see them. Ye Gods, by our trust in you ! what a crowd there is in the Forum! What a lot of people are squabbling there! Aloud. Then provisions are so dear. Aside. What to say besides, I don't know. CHREMES passes by MYSIS, and goes to a distance at the back of the stage.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Pray, why did you leave me here alone?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: pretending to start on seeing the child. Ha! what story is this? How now, Mysis, whence comes this child? Who has brought it here?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Are you quite right in your senses, to be asking me that?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Whom, then, ought I to ask, as I don't see any one else here?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart to himself. I wonder whence it has come.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Are you going to tell me what I ask?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Pshaw !

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: in a whisper. Step aside to the right. They retire on one side.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: You are out of your senses; didn't you your own self?

sp.speaker: DAY.
sp.p: in a low voice. Take you care not to utter a single word beyond what I ask you. Why don't you say aloud whence it comes?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: in a loud voice. From our house.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: affecting indignation. Heyday, indeed! it really is a wonder if a woman, who is a courtesan, acts impudently.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. So far as I can learn, this woman belongs to the Andrian.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Do we seem to you such very suitable persons for you to be playing tricks with us in this way?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. I came just in time.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Make haste then, and take the child away from the door here: in a low voice stay there; take care you don't stir from that spot.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: aside. May the Gods confound you! you do so terrify poor me.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: in a loud voice. Is it to you I speak or not?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: What is it you want?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud. What--do you ask me again? Tell me, whose child have you been laying here? Let me know.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Don't you know?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: in a low voice. Have done with what I know; tell me what I ask.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: aloud. It belongs to your people.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud. Which of our people?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: aloud. To Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: affecting surprise in a loud tone. How? What--to Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: aloud. How now--is it not so?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. With good reason have I always been averse to this match, it's clear.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: calling aloud. O abominable piece of effrontery!

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Why are you bawling out so?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud. What, the very one I saw being carried to your house yesterday evening?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: O you impudent fellow!

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud. It's the truth. I saw Canthara stuffed out beneath her clothes. Stuffed out beneath her clothes: "Suffarcinatam." He alludes to the trick already referred to as common among the Greeks, of the nurses and midwives secretly introducing supposititious children; see 1. 515 and the Note.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: I'faith, I thank the Gods that several free women were present Several free women were present: She speaks of "liberae," "free women," because in Greece as well as Italy slaves were not permitted to give evidence. See the Curculio of Plautus, 1. 621, and the Note to the passage in Bohn's Translation. See also the remark of Geta in the Phormio, 1. 293. at the delivery.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud. Assuredly she doesn't know him, on whose account she resorts to these schemes. Chremes, she fancies, if he sees the child laid before the door, will not give his daughter; i'faith, he'll give her all the sooner.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. I'faith, he'll not do so.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud. Now therefore, that you may be quite aware, if you don't take up the child, I'll roll it forthwith into the middle of the road; and yourself in the same place I'll roll over into the mud.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Upon my word, man, you are not sober.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud. One scheme brings on another. I now hear it whispered about that she is a citizen of Attica----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. Ha!

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud. And that, constrained by the laws, Constrained by the laws: He alludes to a law at Athens which compelled a man who had debauched a free-born woman to marry her. This is said by Davus with the view of frightening Chremes from the match. he will have to take her as his wife.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Well now, pray, is she not a citizen?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. I had almost fallen unawares into a comical misfortune. Comes forward.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Who's that, speaking? Pretending to look about. O Chremes, you have come in good time. Do listen to this.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I have heard it all already.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Prithee, did you hear it? Here's villainy for you! she pointing at MYSIS ought to be carried off She ought to be carried off: He says this implying that Mysis, who is a slave, ought to be put to the torture to confess the truth; as it was the usual method at Athens to force a confession from slaves by that method. We find in the Hecyra, Bacchis readily offering her slaves to be put to the torture, and in the Adelphi the same custom is alluded to in the Scene between Micio, Hegio and Geta. hence to the torture forthwith. To MYSIS, pointing at CHREMES. This is Chremes himself; don't suppose that you are trifling with Davus only.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Wretched me! upon my faith I have told no untruth, my worthy old gentleman.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I know the whole affair. Is Simo within?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: He is. CHREMES goes into SIMO'S house.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: DAVUS attempting to caress her. Don't touch me, villain. Moving away. On my word, if I don't tell Glycerium all this----

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: How now, simpleton, don't you know what has been done?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: How should I know?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: This is the bride's father. It couldn't any other way have been managed that he should know the things that we wanted him to know.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: You should have told me that before.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Do you suppose that it makes little difference whether you do things according to impulse, as nature prompts, or from premeditation?

div2.stage: Enter CRITO, looking about him.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: to himself. It was said that Chrysis used to live in this street, who preferred to gain wealth here dishonorably to living honestly as a poor woman in her own country: by her death that property has descended to me by law. Descended to me by law: On the supposition that Chrysis died without a will, Crito as her next of kin would be entitled to her effects. But I see some persons of whom to make inquiry. Accosting them. Good-morrow to you.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Prithee, whom do I see? Isn't this Crito, the kinsman of Chrysis? It is he.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: O Mysis, greetings to you.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Welcome to you, Crito.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Is Chrysis then ----? Is Chrysis then ----?: This is an instance of Aposiopesis; Crito, much affected, is unwilling to name the death of Chrysis. It was deemed of ill omen to mention death, and numerous Euphemisms or circumlocutions were employed in order to avid the necessity of doing so. Alas!

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: Too truly. She has indeed left us poor creatures quite heart-broken.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: How fare you here, and in what fashion? Pretty well?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: What, we? Just as we can, as they say; since we can't as we would.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: How is Glycerium? Has she discovered her parents yet?

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: I wish she had.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: What, not yet? With no favorable omen did I set out for this place; for, upon my faith, if I had known that, I never would have moved a foot hither. She was always said to be, and was looked upon as her sister; what things were hers she is in possession of; now for me to begin a suit at law here, the precedents of others warn me, a stranger, Warn me, a stranger: Patrick has the following remarks upon this passage: "Madame Dacier observes that it appears, from Xenophon's Treatise on the policy of the Athenians, that all the inhabitants of cities and islands in alliance with Athens were obliged in all claims to repair thither, and refer their cause to the decision of the people, not being permitted to plead elsewhere. We can not wonder then that Crito is unwilling to engage in a suit so inconvenient from its length, expense, and little prospect of success." She might have added that such was the partiality and corruptness of the Athenian people, that, being a stranger, his chances of success would probably be materially diminished. how easy and profitable a task it would be for me. At the same time, I suppose that by this she has got some friend and protector; for she was pretty nearly a grown-up girl when she left there. They would cry out that I am a sharper; that, a pauper, I'm hunting after an inheritance; besides, I shouldn't like to strip the girl herself.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: O most worthy stranger! I'faith, Crito, you still adhere to your good old-fashioned ways.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Lead me to her, since I have come hither, that I may see her.

sp.speaker: MYSIS
sp.p: By all means. They go into the house of GLYCERIUM.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: to himself. I'll follow them; I don't wish the old man to see me at this moment. He follows MYSIS and CRITO.

div2.stage: Enter CHREMES and SIMO from the house of SIMO.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Enough already, enough, Simo, has my friendship toward you been proved. Sufficient hazard have I begun to encounter; make an end of your entreaties, then. While I've been endeavoring to oblige you, I've almost fooled away my daughter's prospects in life.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Nay but, now in especial, Chremes, I do beg and entreat of you, that the favor, commenced a short time since in words, you'll now complete by deeds.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: See how unreasonable you are from your very earnestness; so long as you effect what you desire, you neither think of limits to compliance, nor what it is you request of me; for if you did think, you would now forbear to trouble me with unreasonable requests.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What unreasonable requests?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do you ask? You importuned me to promise my daughter to a young man engaged in another attachment, averse to the marriage state, to plunge her into discord and a marriage of uncertain duration; that through her sorrow and her anguish I might reclaim your son. You prevailed; while the case admitted of it I made preparations. Now it does not admit of it; you must put up with it; they say that she is a citizen of this place; a child has been born; do cease to trouble us.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: By the Gods, I do conjure you not to bring your mind to believe those whose especial interest it is that he should be as degraded as possible. On account of the marriage, have all these things been feigned and contrived. When the reason for which they do these things is removed from them, they will desist.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: You are mistaken; I myself saw the servant-maid wrangling with Davus.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: sneeringly. I am aware.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: With an appearance of earnestness, when neither at the moment perceived that I was present there.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I believe it; and Davus a short time since forewarned me that this would be the case; and I don't know how I forgot to tell it you to-day, as I had intended.

div2.stage: Enter DAVUS from the house of GLYCERIUM.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: aloud at the door, not seeing SIMO and CHREMES. Now then, I bid you set your minds at ease.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to SIMO. See you, there's Davus.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: From what house is he coming out?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: to himself. Through my means, and that of the stranger----

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: overhearing. What mischief is this?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: to himself. I never did see a more opportune person, encounter, or occasion.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: The rascal! I wonder who it is he's praising?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: All the affair is now in a safe position.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why do I delay to accost him?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: to himself, catching sight of SIMO. It's my master; what am I to do?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: accosting him. O, save you, good sir!

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: affecting surprise. Hah! Simo! O, Chremes, my dear sir, all things are now quite ready in-doors.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: ironically. You have taken such very good care.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Send for the bride when you like.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Very good: ironically of course, that's the only thing that's now wanting here. But do you answer me this, what business had you there? Pointing to the house of GLYCERIUM.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Yes, you.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I went in just now.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: As if I asked how long ago!

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Together with your son.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What, is Phamphilus in there? Aside. To my confusion, I'm on the rack! To DAVUS. How now? Didn't you say that there was enmity between them, you scoundrel?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why is he there, then?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why do you. suppose he is? Ironically. Quarreling with her, of course.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Nay but, Chremes, I'll let you now hear from me a disgraceful piece of business. An old man, I don't know who he is, has just now come here; look you, he is a confident and shrewd person; when you look at his appearance, he seems to be a person of some consequence. There is a grave sternness in his features, and something commanding in his words.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What news are you bringing, I wonder?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Why nothing but what I heard him mention.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What does he say then?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: That he knows Glycerium to be a citizen of Attica.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p:
going to his door. Ho there! Dromo, Dromo!
Enter DROMO hastily from the house.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Dromo!

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Hear me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: If you add a word----Dromo!

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Hear me, pray.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: to SIMO. What do you want?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: pointing to DAVUS. Carry him off on your shoulders in-doors as fast as possible.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Davus.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Because I choose. To. DROMO. Carry him off, I say.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Carry him off.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: If you find that I have told a lie in any one matter, then kill me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'll hear nothing. I'll soon have you set in motion. You set in motion: By the use of the word "Commotus" he seems to allude to the wretched, restless existence of a man tied hand and foot, and continually working at the hand-mill. Westerhovius thinks that Simo uses this word sarcastically, in allusion to the words of Davus, at the beginning of the present Scene, "Animo otioso esse impero;" "I bid you set your minds at ease."

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What? Although this is the truth.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: In spite of it. To DROMO. Take care he's kept well secured; and, do you hear? Tie him up hands and feet together. Hands and feet together: "Quadrupedem." Literally "as a quadruped" or "all fours." Echard remarks that it was the custom of the Athenians to tie criminals hands and feet together, just like calves. Now then, be off; upon my faith this very day, if I live, I'll teach you what hazard there is in deceiving a master, and him in deceiving a father. DROMO leads DAVUS into the house.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Oh, don't be so extremely vexed.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: O Chremes, the dutifulness of a son! Do you not pity me? That I should endure so much trouble for such a son! Goes to the door of GLYCERIUM'S house. Come, Pamphilus, come out, Pamphilus! have you any shame left?

div2.stage: Enter PAMPHILUS in haste from GLYCERIUM'S house.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Who is it that wants me? Aside. I'm undone! it's my father.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What say you, of all men, the ----?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Oh! rather speak about the matter itself, and forbear to use harsh language.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: As if any thing too severe could now be possibly said against him. Pray, do you say that Glycerium is a citizen---

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: So they say.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: So they say! Unparalleled assurance! does he consider what he says? Is he sorry for what he has done? Does his countenance, pray, at all betray any marks of shame? That he should be of mind so weak, as, without regard to the custom and the law Without regard to the custom and the law: There was a law among the Athenians which forbade citizens to marry strangers, and made the offspring of such alliances illegitimate; the same law also excluded such as were not born of two citizens from all offices of trust and honor. of his fellow-citizens, and the wish of his own father, to be anxious, in spite of every thing, to have her, to his own utter disgrace!

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Miserable that I am!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Ha! have you at last found that out only just now, Pamphilus? Long since did that expression, long since, when you made up your mind, that what you desired must be effected by you at any price; from that very day did that expression aptly befit you. But yet why do I torment myself? Why vex myself? Why worry my old age with this madness? Am I to suffer the punishment for his offenses? Nay then, let him have her, good-by to him, let him pass his life with her.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: My father----

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: How, "my father?" As if you stood in any need of this father. Home, wife, and children, provided by you against the will of your father! People suborned, too, to say that she is a citizen of this place! You have gained your point.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Father, may I say a few words?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What can you say to me?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: But, Simo, do hear him.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I, hear him? Why should I hear him, Chremes?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Still, however, do allow him to speak.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Well then, let him speak: I allow him.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I own that I love her; if that is committing a fault, I own that also. To you, father, do I subject myself. Impose on me any injunction you please; command me. Do you wish me to take a wife? Do you wish me to give her up? As well as I can I will endure it. This only I request of you, not to think that this old gentleman has been suborned by me. Allow me to clear myself, and to bring him here before you.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: To bring him here?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Do allow me, father.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: He asks what's reasonable; do give him leave.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Allow me to obtain thus much of you.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I allow it. I desire any thing, so long as I find, Chremes, that I have not been deceived by him. PAMPHILUS goes into the house of GLYCERIUM.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For a great offense, a slight punishment ought to satisfy a father.

div2.stage: Re-enter PAMPHILUS with CRITO.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: to PAMPHILUS, as he is coming out. Forbear entreating. Of these, any one reason prompts me to do it, either your own sake, or the fact that it is the truth, or that I wish well for Glycerium herself.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: starting. Do I see Crito of Andros? Surely it is he.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Greetings to you, Chremes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: How is it that, so contrary to your usage, you are at Athens?

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: So it has happened. But is this Simo?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It is he.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Simo, were you asking for me?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: How now, do you say that Glycerium is a citizen of this place?

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Do you deny it?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: ironically. Have you come here so well prepared?

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: For what purpose?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Do you ask? Are you to be acting this way with impunity? Are you to be luring young men into snares here, inexperienced in affairs, and liberally brought up, by tempting them, and to be playing upon their fancies by making promises?

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Are you in your senses?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: And are you to be patching up amours with Courtesans by marriage?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: aside. I'm undone! I fear that the stranger will not put up with this.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: If, Simo, you knew this person well, you would not think thus; he is a worthy man.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: He, a worthy man! To come so opportunely to-day just at the very nuptials, and yet never to have come before? Ironically. Of course, we must believe him, Chremes.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: aside. If I didn't dread my father, I have something, which, in this conjuncture, I could opportunely suggest to him Could opportunely suggest to him: Colman has the following remark on this line: "Madame Dacier and several English Translators make Pamphilus say that he could give Crito a hint or two. What hints he could propose to suggest to Crito, I can not conceive. The Italian translation, printed with the Vatican Terence, seems to understand the words in the same manner that I have translated them, in which sense (the pronoun 'ilium' referring to Simo instead of Crito) they seem to be the most natural words of Pamphilus on occasion of his father's anger and the speech immediately preceding."

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: sneeringly, to CHREMES. A sharper! A sharper: "Sycophanta." For some account of the "sycophantae," "swindlers" or "sharpers" of ancient times, see the Notes to the Trinummus of Plautus, Bohn's Translation.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: starting. Hah!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It is his way, Crito; do excuse it.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Let him take heed how he behaves. If he persists in saying to me what he likes, he'll be hearing things that he don't like. Am I meddling with these matters or interesting myself? Can you not endure your troubles with a patient mind? For as to what I say, whether it is true or false what I have heard, can soon be known. A certain man of Attica, a long time ago, A long time ago: The story begins with "Olim," just in the same way that with us nursery tales commence with "There was, a long time ago." his ship being wrecked, was cast ashore at Andros, and this woman together with him, who was then a little girl; he, in his destitution, by chance first made application to the father of Chrysis----

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: ironically. He's beginning his tale.

sp.speaker: CHREM.
sp.p: Let him alone.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Really, is he to be interrupting me in this way?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do you proceed.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: He who received him was a relation of mine. There I heard from him that he was a native of Attica. He died there.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: The name, in such a hurry!

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Phania.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: starting. Hah! I shall die!

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.p: I'faith, I really think it was Phania; this I know for certain, he said that he was a citizen of Rhamnus. A citizen of Rhamnus: Rhamnus was a maritime town of Attica, near which many of the more wealthy Athenians had country-seats. It was famous for the Temple of Nemesis there, the Goddess of Vengeance, who was thence called "Rhamnusia." In this Temple was her statue, carved by Phidias out of the marble which the Persians brought to Greece for the purpose of making a statue of Victory out of it, and which was thus appropriately devoted to the Goddess of Retribution. The statue wore a crown, and had wings, and, holding a spear of ash in the right hand, it was seated on a stag.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: O Jupiter!

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Many other persons in Andros have heard the same, Chremes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: aside. I trust it may turn out as I hope. To CRITO. Come now, tell me, what did he then say about her? Did he say she was his own daughter?

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Whose then?

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: His brother's daughter.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: She certainly is mine.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What is this that you say?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: aside. Prick up your ears, Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why do you suppose so?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: That Phania was my brother.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I knew him, and I am aware of it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: He, flying from the wars, and following me to Asia, set out from here. At the same time he was afraid to leave her here behind; since then, this is the first time I have heard what became of him.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: aside. I am scarcely myself, so much has my mind been agitated by fear, hope, joy, and surprise at this so great, so unexpected blessing.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Really, I am glad for many reasons that she has been discovered to be a citizen.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I believe it, father.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: But there yet remains one difficulty One difficulty: "Scrupus," or "scrupulus," was properly a stone or small piece of gravel which, getting into the shoe, hurt the foot; hence the word figuratively came to mean a "scruple," "difficulty," or "doubt." We have a similar expression: "to be graveled." with me, which keeps me in suspense.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: aside. You deserve to be ----, with your scruples, you plague. You are seeking a knot in a bulrush. A knot in a bulrush: "Nodum in scirpo quaerere" was a proverbial expression implying a desire to create doubts and difficulties where there really were none; there being no knots in the bulrush. The same expression occurs in the Menaechmi of Plautus, 1. 247.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: to CHREMES. What is that?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: The names don't agree.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: Troth, she had another when little.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What was it, Crito? Can you remember it?

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: I'm trying to recollect it.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: aside. Am I to suffer his memory to stand in the way of my happiness, when I myself can provide my own remedy in this matter? I will not suffer it. Aloud. Hark you, Chremes, that which you are trying to recollect is "Pasibula."

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: That's it.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I've heard it from herself a thousand times.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I suppose, Chremes, that you believe that we all rejoice at this discovery.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: So may the Gods bless me, I do believe it.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: What remains to be done, father?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: The event itself has quite brought me to reconcilement.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: O kind father! With regard to her as a wife, since I have taken possession of her, Chremes will not offer any opposition.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: The plea is a very good one, unless perchance your father says any thing to the contrary.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Of course, I agree.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Then be it so. Of course----Then be it so: "Nempe id. Scilicet." Colman has the following remark on this line: "Donatus, and some others after him, understand these words of Simo and Pamphilus as requiring a fortune of Chremes with his daughter; and one of them' says that Simo, in order to explain his meaning, in the representation, should produce a bag of money. This surely is precious refinement, worthy the genius of a true Commentator. Madame Dacier, who entertains a just veneration for Donatus, doubts the authenticity of the observation ascribed to him. The sense I have followed is, I think, the most obvious and natural' interpretation of the words of Pamphilus and Simo, which refers to the preceding, not the subsequent, speech of Chremes."

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Her portion, Pamphilus, is ten talents.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I alm satisfied.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll hasten to my daughter. Come now, beckoning along with me, Crito; for I suppose that she will not know me. They go into GLYCERIUM'S house.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: To PAMPHILUS. Why don't you order her to be sent for hither, to our house?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Well thought of; I'll at once give charge of that to Davus.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: He can't do it.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Because he has another matter that more nearly concerns himself, and of more importance.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: What, pray?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: He is bound.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Father, he is not rightly bound. He is not rightly bound: "Non recte vinctus;" meaning it was not well done to bind him." The father pretends to understand him as meaning (which he might equally well by using the same words), "non satis stricte," "he wasn't tightly enough" bound; and answers "I ordered that he should be," referring to his order for Davus to be bound hand and foot. Donatus justly observes that the disposition of the old gentleman to joke is a characteristic mark of his thorough reconciliation.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: But I ordered to that effect.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Prithee, do order him to be set at liberty,

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Well, be it so.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: But immediately.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'm going in.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: O fortunate and happy day! SIMO goes into his house.

div2.stage: Enter CHARINUS, at a distance.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: apart to himself. I'm come to see what Pamphilus is about; and look, here he is.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: to himself. Some one perhaps might imagine that I don't believe this to be true; but now it is clear to me that it really is true. I do think that the life of the Gods is everlasting, for this reason, because their joys are their own. Their joys are their own: Westerhovius remarks that he seems here to be promulgating the doctrine of Epicurus, who taught that the Deities devoted themselves entirely to pleasure and did not trouble themselves about mortals. Donatus observes that these are the doctrines of Epicurus, and that the whole sentence is copied from the Eunuch of Menander; to which practice of borrowing from various Plays, allusion is made in the Prologue, where he mentions the mixing of plays; "contaminari fabulas." For immortality has been obtained by me, if no sorrow interrupts this delight. But whom in particular could I wish to be now thrown in my way, for me to relate these things to?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: apart to himself. What means this rapture?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: to himself. I see Davus. There is no one in the world whom I would choose in preference; for I am sure that he of all people will sincerely rejoice in my happiness.

div2.stage: Enter DAVUS.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: to himself. Where is Pamphilus, I wonder?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Here he is, Davus.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: turning round. Who's that?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: 'Tis I, Pamphilus; you don't know what has happened to me.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: No really; but I know what has happened to myself.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: And I too.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: It has fallen out just like human affairs in general, that you should know the mishap I have met with, before I the good that has befallen you.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: My Glycerium has discovered her parents.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: O, well done!

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: apart, in surprise. Hah!

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Her father is an intimate friend of ours.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Chremes.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: You do tell good news.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: And there's no hinderance to my marrying her at once.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: apart. Is he dreaming the same that he has been wishing for when awake?

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Then about the child, Davus.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: O, say no more; you are the only person whom the Gods favor.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: apart. I'm all right if these things are true. I'll accost them. Comes forward.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Who is this? Why, Charinus, you meet me at the very nick of time.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: That's all right.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: Have you heard----?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Every thing; come, in your good fortune do have some regard for me. Chremes is now at your command; I'm sure that he'll do every thing you wish.

sp.speaker: PAMPHILUS
sp.p: I'll remember you; and because it is tedious for us to wait for him until he comes out, follow me this way; he is now in-doors at the house of Glycerium; do you, Davus, go home; send with all haste to remove her thence. Why are you standing there? Why are you delaying?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I'm going. PAMPHILUS and CHARINUS go into the house of GLYCERIUM. DAVUS then comes forward and addresses the Audience. Don't you wait until they come out from there; she will be betrothed within: if there is any thing else that remains, it will be transacted in-doors. Grant us your applause.Grant us your applause: "Plaudite." Colman has the following remark at the conclusion of this Play: "All the old Tragedies and Comedies acted at Rome concluded in this manner. 'Donec cantor vos "Plaudite" dicat,' says Horace. Who the 'cantor' was, is a matter of dispute. Madame Dacier thinks it was the whole chorus; others suppose it to have been a single actor; some the prompter, and some the composer. Before the word 'Plaudite' in all the old copies is an *w, which has also given rise to several learned conjectures. It is most probable, according to the notion of Madame Dacier, that this *w, being the last letter of the Greek alphabet, was nothing more than the mark of the transcriber to signify the end, like the Latin word 'Finis' in modern books; or it might, as Patrick supposes, stand for *wdos, 'cantor,' denoting that the following word 'Plaudite' was spoken by him. After 'Plaudite' in all the old copies of Terence stand these two words, 'Calliopins recensui;' which signify, 'I, Calliopius, have revised and corrected this piece.' And this proceeds from the custom of the old critics, who carefully revised all Manuscripts, and when they had read and corrected any work, certified the same by placing their names at the end of it."
